Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Consequences of Cell-to-Cell Mechanical Variation in the Heart

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The heart is made of millions of individual muscle cells that must contract together in a coordinated way to pump blood. Because the cells must work together, they are electrically connected to one another to synchronize beating. It might have been expected that the strength and speed of contraction would be the same in neighboring cells. However, when cells are separate, their mechanical behavior is surprisingly different. It is not clear how these cells, being so different mechanically, still work together to produce efficient pumping. In this project, cell-to-cell mechanical variation will be measured in small samples of heart tissue. From this information, an accurate computer model of heart tissue can be created. The model will help explain how cell-to-cell variation impacts overall tissue function. Finally, the predictions made by the model will be tested in engineered heart tissues, which allow the amount of cell variability to be adjusted and studied. This work is significant because cell variability tends to increase with aging and in certain diseases. A clearer understanding of how variation contributes to normal and abnormal heart function could ultimately inspire effective treatments for cardiac disorders that are currently incurable.

New data suggest that adjacent cells from healthy heart tissue display substantial mechanical differences. How this 'microscale heterogeneity' affects the mechanical function of bulk myocardium has never been studied, but has far-reaching implications. This project examines the impact of microscale heterogeneity by testing two hypotheses: (1) That it has an appreciable influence on myocardial contraction even in normal hearts, and (2) That increasing microscale heterogeneity beyond normal limits disrupts tissue function. After measuring the nature and scope of microscale heterogeneity, its effects on tissue mechanical behavior will be predicted using a novel multiscale computational model. This model is comprised of a biophysically detailed muscle contraction model embedded in a finite element mesh for simulation of three-dimensional tissue mechanics. The predictions produced by the model can be tested by genetically manipulating cellular heterogeneity in engineered myocardial tissue mimics and measuring their biomechanical characteristics. The aggregate behavior of a network of adjacent but functionally different muscle cells has the potential of displaying new and surprising emergent properties. If proven correct, these hypotheses would shift current opinion on the determinants of myocardial relaxation and tissue homeostasis while shedding light on disease mechanisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award has funded three years of research into how individual heart cells work together to produce an overall contraction. This project was inspired by observations in our laboratory at Yale University. We noticed that single heart cells contract very differently from each other, even when taken from the same heart. We wondered whether this was simply due to the fact that cells had come from different regions of the heart, or if this mixed behavior was true even in very small tissue volumes.

 

In the first phase of this project, we measured the contractile strength and speed of single heart cells, starting with cells from large pieces of tissue and repeating this experiment with progressively smaller tissue pieces. As we measured cells from smaller tissue pieces, we noticed that the cell-to-cell variation diminished, but only to a point. Anything smaller than a 2 millimeter cube did not reduce variation, and in fact, even within these volumes substantial variation still existed among cells. We built a special device that could harvest and sort the fastest-relaxing cells from those that relaxed most slowly. We analyzed these groups chemically and found that fast-relaxers actually had a different protein makeup compared to the slowest cells. This suggested that cell-to-cell differences in contraction happen because of some flexibility in the way each cell is regulated.

 

In the second phase of the project, we studied the possible consequences of this regulatory flexibility and diversity of cell behavior even within a very small tissue volume. We first used a computer model to predict how so many varying cells would interact during a single muscle contraction. The model indicated that even a relatively small population of fast-relaxing cells could promote faster relaxation in the muscle as a whole.

 

To test this idea, we created artificial heart muscle by mixing two different populations of heart cells together and placing them on a biological scaffolding material. Once cell type came from a healthy heart, and the other from a patient with a genetic heart disorder that causes cells to relax more slowly than normal. We found that, just as the model predicted, adding an equal mixture of fast and slow cells produced a tissue that behaved more like a tissue made purely of fast cells. This discovery is significant because it seems to indicate that natural variation among heart cells actually promotes relaxation without altering the overall contraction strength. Relaxation is critical to heart function because the heart must relax in order to fill with blood for the next beat.

 

This research award also funded further innovations and insights in the area of heart cell variability. In the process of making many single-cell measurements, we invented a more efficient technique that involves trapping individual cells in tiny microscopic wells. Once in a well, the cell remains trapped while fluid containing different drugs is flowed over and around it. We used this system to track behavior of cells in response to common heart drugs. The tests showed that no two cells responded in exactly the same way to any of the drugs we tested. We realized that this actually represented a unique opportunity to understand pathways of regulation ? by harvesting cells with unique behavior and analyzing the genes they express, we are discovering roles for genes that were not previously known.

 

Research groups in many scientific fields are beginning to think more about the importance and consequences of cell-to-cell variation in biology. Our work lends further support to the idea that cell variability is important for understanding tissue behavior, and that it can actually be leveraged to make exciting new discoveries. These concepts can be applied to other biological systems to gain fresh insights.

 

This NSF award also funded scientific outreach to Connecticut 6th graders in the form of classroom and laboratory sessions designed to build interest in biological research and teach fundamentals of heart science. Participants learned about devices that measure electrical activity of the heart as well as careers in biomedical engineering and biological research. Laboratory exercises provided each student the opportunity to measure electrical activity of their own heart and explore their own questions about biolectricity.
